_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UNION CARBIDE CORPORATION a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company 

NEW YARD

Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) is a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company. The Union Carbide facilities at South Charleston, Institute, Technology Park, and New Yard share leveraged support and management and are collectively called West Virginia Operations (WVO).  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

WVO is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release should occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also an active member of the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee which provides additional emergency response expertise.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The New Yard is used to temporarily store rail cars for eventual processing at the Institute site. The rail yard is managed by West Virginia Operations Site Logistics, but is not considered contiguous with the Institute site. No chemical loading or unloading takes place at the New Yard.

There is currently one RMP regulated substances present in one covered process at the facility. Isopentane is no longer transported via rail car, and therefore has been removed from the list of RMP regulated substances at New Yard.  UCC stores a threshold quantity of one EPA regulated toxic substance in the New Yard:
¿	Ethylene Oxide

The maximum inventory quantity of ethylene oxide has increased for the 2014 RMP resubmittal due to a revision in estimation methods associated in an increase in average capaci

ty of rail cars.

The RMPComp tool was utilized to provide distance to endpoint of the toxic worst-case scenario, in place of the PHAST Model. 


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

UCC at the New Yard site has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases as defined by the RMP rule of regulated substances, during this period.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

UCC's general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule, OSHA's PSM standard, and implementation of Dow's Operating Discipline Management System and standards. Key elements include:

Process Safety Information
We maintain detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters
and equipment designs associated with all covered processes. Examples include, but are not limited to, Material Safety Data Sheets for all the hazardous chemicals, equipment design specification sheets, and reactive chemicals test results. This information is maintained up-to-date and is available to operating personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified, evaluated, and controlled efficiently. The methodologies used to carry out these analyses may include: Checklists, What If/Checklists (combined), Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOP's), Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analyses, Chemical Exposure Index, Fire & Explosion Index, and Layers of Protection Analyses. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, WVO maintains written opera

ting procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
WVO has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes
are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided
on a continuing basis.

Mechanical Integrity
WVO carries out a documented Planned Preventative Maintenance Program (PPM) which provides checks on
process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes, but
is not limited to: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency
shutdown systems, controls, pumps, and compressors. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified
personnel with training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized
training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe
and timely manner.

Management of Change
WVO facilities require management of modifications to process equipment, procedures, raw materials, and
processing conditions other than "like for like", by identifying, documenting, and reviewing them prior to
implementation of changes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job
tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training
prior to the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are
conducted at WVO. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and
maintenance procedures are suitable for safe s

tartup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Self assessments and audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. Audits are conducted using established schedules and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
WVO promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a significant release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
WVO believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. UCC employees and
contracted employees working in UCC Institute plants are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees and contracted employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
WVO hires contractors to perform some specialized operations, maintenance and construction activities. Prior to
selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed. WVO has
a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and
the processes he/she may encounter while on site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for
emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during e

mergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee and the community.

New Yard is covered by the emergency response plant of the Institute Site. The Institute Site has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post- incident decontamination of affected areas. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.

To ensure proper functioning, quarterly emergency drills are conducted to enhance skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release. Critiques are held on drills and actual events. Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.

Kanawha/Putnam EPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which Institute's emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Recent improvements include the newest generation GPS tracking devices installed through the EO fleet.  Rigid preventative maintenance testing is performed that goes beyond the industry standard.  

Although routine reviews and leveraged best practices may identify improvement opportunities, no additional projects are currently planned.
